verses.text: After David had finished speaking to Saul, the soul of Jonathan was knit to the soul of David, and Jonathan loved him as his own soul.
verses.comment: The phrase 'knit to the soul' translates the Hebrew idiom for deep friendship.

verses.text: And Saul took him that day and would not let him return to his father's house.
verses.comment: Saul brings David into his service permanently.

verses.text: Then Jonathan made a covenant with David, because he loved him as his own soul.
verses.comment: Emphasizes the seriousness of Jonathan's commitment to David.

verses.text: And Jonathan took off the robe that was on him and gave it to David, along with his armor, and even his sword, his bow, and his belt.
verses.comment: Transferring these items symbolizes honor, friendship, and possibly Jonathan's recognition of David's future role.

verses.text: And David went out and was successful wherever Saul sent him, so that Saul set him over the men of war. And this was good in the eyes of all the people and also in the eyes of Saul's servants.
verses.comment: 'Was successful' translates the Hebrew idea of behaving wisely and prospering.

verses.text: As they were coming home, when David returned from striking down the Philistine, the women came out from all the cities of Israel, singing and dancing, to meet King Saul, with tambourines, with songs of joy, and with musical instruments.
verses.comment: The procession and celebration is similar to prior biblical victory celebrations.

verses.text: And the women sang to one another as they celebrated, 'Saul has struck down his thousands, and David his tens of thousands.'
verses.comment: The chant expresses David’s growing reputation greater than Saul’s.

verses.text: And Saul was very angry, and this saying displeased him. He said, 'They have ascribed to David tens of thousands, and to me they have ascribed thousands. What more can he have but the kingdom?'
verses.comment: Saul's jealousy emerges over David’s popularity.

verses.text: And Saul eyed David from that day on.
verses.comment: To ‘eye’ means to keep a jealous watch on him.

verses.text: The next day a harmful spirit from God rushed upon Saul, and he raved within his house while David was playing the lyre as he did day by day. Saul had his spear in his hand.
verses.comment: ‘A harmful spirit from God’ - understanding God’s sovereignty, not direct causation of evil.

verses.text: And Saul hurled the spear, for he thought, 'I will pin David to the wall.' But David evaded him twice.
verses.comment: David avoids Saul’s attempted attack.

verses.text: Saul was afraid of David, because the LORD was with him but had departed from Saul.
verses.comment: Faithful rendering; 'departed from Saul' means God's favor left Saul.

verses.text: So Saul removed him from his presence and made him a commander over a thousand. And he went out and came in before the people.
verses.comment: Saul attempted to distance David by sending him on military duty.

verses.text: And David was successful in all his ways, for the LORD was with him.
verses.comment: 'Successful' translates Hebrew idiom for acting wisely and prospering.

verses.text: And when Saul saw that he was very successful, he stood in fear of him.
verses.comment: Saul is increasingly fearful due to David's success.

verses.text: But all Israel and Judah loved David, because he went out and came in before them.
verses.comment: 'Went out and came in' refers to David’s leadership in battle and public presence.

verses.text: Then Saul said to David, 'Here is my older daughter Merab. I will give her to you as a wife; only be a valiant man for me and fight the LORD’s battles.' For Saul thought, 'Let not my hand be against him, but let the hand of the Philistines be against him.'
verses.comment: Saul tries to use his daughter as a trap for David.

verses.text: And David said to Saul, 'Who am I, and who are my relatives or my father’s clan in Israel, that I should be son-in-law to the king?'
verses.comment: David expresses humility about his family status.

verses.text: But at the time when Merab, Saul’s daughter, should have been given to David, she was given to Adriel the Meholathite as wife.
verses.comment: Saul gives his daughter to another instead of David.

verses.text: Now Saul’s daughter Michal loved David, and they told Saul, and the thing pleased him.
verses.comment: 'Loved' here means romantic affection.

verses.text: Saul thought, 'I will give her to him, that she may be a snare for him, and that the hand of the Philistines may be against him.' Therefore Saul said to David a second time, 'You shall now be my son-in-law.'
verses.comment: Saul's intent is again malicious—hoping to get rid of David via the Philistines.

verses.text: And Saul commanded his servants, 'Speak to David in private and say, “Behold, the king delights in you, and all his servants love you; now then become the king’s son-in-law.”'
verses.comment: Saul plots through persuasive flattery.

verses.text: And Saul’s servants spoke those words to David. But David said, 'Does it seem to you a small thing to become the king’s son-in-law, since I am a poor man and have no reputation?'
verses.comment: 'No reputation'—literally, 'lightly esteemed.'

verses.text: And the servants of Saul told him, 'Thus and so did David speak.'
verses.comment: Direct literal reporting, as in the original text.

verses.text: Then Saul said, 'Thus you shall say to David, “The king desires no bride price except one hundred foreskins of the Philistines, that he may be avenged of the king’s enemies.”' Now Saul thought to make David fall by the hand of the Philistines.
verses.comment: The 'bride price' is a dangerous task intended to get David killed.

verses.text: And when his servants told David these words, it pleased David well to be the king’s son-in-law. Before the time had expired,
verses.comment: David welcomes the challenge.

verses.text: David arose and went, he and his men, and killed two hundred Philistines. Then David brought their foreskins, which were counted out in full to the king, that he might become the king’s son-in-law. And Saul gave him his daughter Michal as wife.
verses.comment: David goes beyond the requirement, showing his zeal and capability.

verses.text: But when Saul saw and knew that the LORD was with David, and that Michal, Saul’s daughter, loved him,
verses.comment: Saul realizes David’s favor with both God and his daughter.

verses.text: Saul was even more afraid of David. So Saul was David’s enemy continually.
verses.comment: The Hebrew is explicit about the ongoing nature of the enmity.

verses.text: Then the commanders of the Philistines came out to battle, and as often as they came out, David behaved more wisely than all the servants of Saul, so that his name was highly esteemed.
verses.comment: ‘Behaved more wisely’ reflects the idiom for prospering with skill and discernment.
